Award.AwardTitle: Memory encoding in spatially structured networks: dynamics, discrete geometry & topology
Award.AbstractNarration:
Hippocampal networks are believed to be a major center of associative learning due to the central role of the hippocampus in learning and memory, as well as the relatively high levels of recurrent connectivity and synaptic plasticity. The lack of topographic structure in hippocampus has made it a natural inspiration for associative memory models, such as the Hopfield model, for encoding memories in unstructured recurrent networks. At the same time, studies in rodents have uncovered the critical role of hippocampus in spatial navigation and, more recently, time-tracking. In contrast to associative memory encoding, these functions have been successfully modeled using spatially structured networks. How can these viewpoints be reconciled? The central goal of this research is to develop a mathematical theory of memory encoding in spatially structured networks, and to study the neural codes that arise from such networks. Specifically, the research will develop mathematical theory to answer the following questions: (1) How can overlapping memory patterns be encoded precisely as attractors of an unstructured neural network, without introducing unwanted "spurious states"? (2) How can memories be encoded in a spatially structured network, such as a bump attractor network, while maintaining functions that depend on the network's spatial organization? (3) Aside from error correction, what are the advantages of redundancy in a neural code, such as the hippocampal place field code, that is characterized by heavily overlapping receptive fields? This last question will also be explored via the analysis of cortical and hippocampal data sets provided by collaborating labs.

The hippocampus is often thought of as a "Swiss knife" in the brain. Decades of experimental work have uncovered its essential role in learning and memory, as well as in spatial navigation. From a theoretical standpoint, it is puzzling how the same neural network can achieve such disparate functions. In particular, mathematical models of memory encoding are fundamentally quite different from models of spatial navigation. This work will integrate these two major types of neural network models, with the goal of understanding how the hippocampus can support multiple important functions. At its core, the research will advance the mathematical theory behind our understanding of network-level computation in the brain.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Topological analysis of pairwise correlations. In collaboration with Chad Giusti (a post-doc), Eva Pastalkova (an experimental neuroscientist), and Vladimir Itskov, we have developed a novel paradigm for analyzing pairwise correlations in neural data. Specifically, we've developed the framework of clique topology to analyze symmetric matrices with hidden nonlinearities. This associates topological invariants, called Betti curves, to matrices. Crucially, the Betti curves can be used to detect both geometric structure and randomness in symmetric matrices in a way that is insensitive to nonlinear monotone transformations of the matrix entries. They thus provide an alternative approach to eigenvalue-based analyses, as the eigenvalue spectrum may be greatly altered by nonlinearities (see Figure 1). This work resulted in publication #5, below.

Theory of threshold-linear networks. Motivated by trying to understand memory encoding in bump attractor networks, the PI has further developed the theory of symmetric threshold-linear networks in the case of constant external input. In this case, threshold-linear networks act as traditional Hopfield-style attractor networks, but have the advantage of being both more biologically realistic and more mathematically tractable. Some suprisingly strong theoretical results on the structure of fixed points in these networks have been obtained by exploiting a newly-discovered connection to distance geometry. This work resulted in publications #3 and 7, below.

Algebraic structure of neural codes. Neural codes in many brain areas capture the structure of receptive fields, which in turn reveals information about the underlying stimulus spaces being encoded by neural activity (see Figure 2). Together with a graduate student, Nora Youngs, and other collaborators, the PI has developed an algebraic framework that captures combinatorial and geometric properties of neural codes. This work resulted in publications #1, 2, 8 and 9, below.

Dynamics of vesicle replenishment for ribbon synapses. In collaboration with a graduate student, Caitlyn Parmelee, and the Thoreson lab at the University of Nebraska Medical Center (UNMC, in Omaha), the PI developed models of of vesicle release and replenishment. This work resulted in publications #4 and 6, below.

Publications

The award resulted in 9 papers:

1. C. Curto, V. Itskov, K. Morrison, Z. Roth, J.L. Walker. Combinatorial neural codes from a mathematical coding theory perspective. Neural Computation, Vol 25(7), pp. 1891-1925, 2013.

2. C. Curto, V. Itskov, A. Veliz-Cuba, N. Youngs. The neural ring: an algebraic tool for analyzing the intrinsic structure of neural codes. Bulletin of Mathematical Biology, Volume 75, Issue 9, pp. 1571-1611, 2013.

3. C. Curto, A. Degeratu, V. Itskov. Encoding binary neural codes in networks of threshold-linear neurons. Neural Computation, Vol 25, pp. 2858?2903, 2013.

4. M.J. Van Hook, C. Parmelee, M. Chen, K.M. Cork, C. Curto, W.B. Thoreson. Calmodulin enhances ribbon replenishment and shapes filtering of synaptic transmission by cone photoreceptors. Journal of General Physiology, 144:357-378, 2014.

5. C. Giusti, E. Pastalkova, C. Curto*, V. Itskov* (*equal last authors). Clique topology reveals intrinsic geometric structure in neural correlations. PNAS, 2015

6. W.B. Thoreson, M.J. Van Hook, C. Parmelee, C. Curto. Modeling and measurement of vesicle pools at the cone ribbon synapse: changes in release probability are solely responsible for voltagedependent changes in release. Synapse, 2016.

7. C. Curto, K. Morrison. Pattern completion in symmetric threshold-linear networks. Neural Computation, Vol 28, pp. 2825-2852, 2016.

8. C. Curto, E. Gross, J. Jeffries, K. Morrison, M. Omar, Z. Rosen, A. Shiu, N. Youngs. What makes a neural code convex? SIAM J. Appl. Algebra and Geometry, vol. 1, pp. 222-238, 2017.

9. C. Curto, N. Youngs. Neural ring homomorphisms and maps between neural codes. (Preprint available at http://arxiv.org/abs/1511.00255)

Broader Impacts

Several graduate students and postdocs advised during the project period:

1. Nora Youngs obtained her PhD in 2014, and is now a tenure-track assistant professor at Colby College.

2. Caitlyn Parmelee obtained her PhD in 2016, and is now a tenure-track assistant professor at Keene State University.

3. Alan Veliz-Cuba was a postdoc with the PI until 2013, and is now a tenure-track assistant professor at University of Dayton.

4. Chad Giusti was a postdoc with the PI from 2012-2014, and is now a tenure-track assistant professor at the University of Delaware.

5. Katherine Morrison was a junior researcher collaborating with the PI on projects related to the grant, and is now a tenured associate professor at the University of Northern Colorado. 

During the grant period, the PI has devoted considerable time and energy to mentoring students and postdocs in her research group. Grant funds were used to partially support lab members to attend summer schools and conferences in computational neuroscience.
